phys::crossplatform Namespace Reference

Detailed Description

All functionality that needs different implemenations per platform will go in here.

If we did our jobs right You not need to change anything to compile on different platforms exvept the build target. If you want, the platform can be manually defined in this section and this should be the only place that you need to change to compile this on a supported platform. Just remark all the lines that are not your platform using "//" and unremark your platform.

Should you choose to port this to your platform, make sure that all the required libraries are installed, then make sure to write an implementation for each of the functions in crossplatform.cpp, then you should get to the nitty gritty of making the minor platforms inconsistencies work.

For most games there will be no need to directly call these functions, however if you decide you game is an exception, there is one key thing to remember about all of these functions. All of these may perform/behave slightly differently.

Function Documentation

string PHYS_LIB phys::crossplatform::GetDataDirectory (  ) 

Gets the Default Data Directory.

The directory returned by this function can be used to easily graphics objects. In general the Graphics subsystem can easily open files in this location with just their filename

Returns:
A string containing the path to the default Data Directory.
string phys::crossplatform::GetPluginsDotCFG (  ) 

Returns a string with a path/filename to the default Plugins config file.

For internal use only.

Plugins.cfg is the file that determines which graphics plugins are loaded. This is a feature of the graphics subsystem and is generally not needed outside of engine code.

Returns:
A string which contains the path and filename of the plugins file
void * phys::crossplatform::GetSDLOgreBinder (  ) 

This creates a data structure that can help SDL(User Input Subsystem) with Ogre(graphics subsystem).

For internal use only.

This creates a data structure that can help SDL(User Input Subsystem) with Ogre(graphics subsystem) This returns a named parameter list with valid settings to use Ogre rendering on a pre-existing SDL context

Warning:
This is an engine internal, and shouldn't be used anywhere else. For all practical purposes is return gibberish
string phys::crossplatform::GetSettingsDotCFG (  ) 

Returns a string with a path/filename to the default Graphics Subsytem settings file.

For internal use only.

Settings.cfg is the file that determines how graphics settings are configured by default. This is a feature of the graphics subsystem and is generally not needed outside of engine code.

Returns:
A string which contains the path and filename of the graphics setts file
void PHYS_LIB phys::crossplatform::RenderPhysWorld ( World *  TheWorld,
Ogre::RenderWindow *  TheOgreWindow 
)

Renders the current world contents to the screen.

This makes use of World internals to Render to the screen, So it is advised against calling this directly. Currently there is no known issue with calling this directly, but it is not thread safe and is run during the main loop at the aproppriate times. Currently this references Ogre systems, that makes this internal Handles the actual cross platform swapping of graphics buffers.

Parameters:
TheWorld This is a pointer to the World to be rendered.
TheWorld A pointer to the game window to be update to be rendered. This is considered an internal component
void PHYS_LIB phys::crossplatform::WaitMilliseconds ( const Whole &  WaitTime  ) 

Pauses the program for a given period of time.

Pauses the program for a given period of time.

Parameters:
WaitTime The amount of time in milliseconds to wait
